column5: So, by this logic, Miami gets to decide that the rest of state is northwest Florida. Am I getting it yet? It still seems confusing, so I may be wrong.

". . . Was there a man dismay'd ? Not tho' the soldier knew Some one had blunder'd: Theirs not to make reply, Theirs not to reason why, Theirs but to do & die, Into the valley of Death Rode the six hundred. . ."Tennyson, The Charge of the Light BrigadeYours is not to reason why some geographically challenged Canuck blundered and called it what he did. Yours is to get your arse up there and fish.
Or that people in Cook County/Chicago think that anything south of I-80 is southern Illinois,,,,, HRG
Toronto isn't the centre of the province, it's the centre of the known universe...ask any Torontonian, they'll set you straight.
I'd like to see a panel discussion on this with people from Toronto, Montreal, Boston, New York and LA. Also a European version with London, Paris, Madrid, Berlin and Rome represented.

The Centre (Center) of the Universe is in Trawna. Just ask anyone in the GTA (Greater Toronto Area). To folks in the Maritimes (New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, PEI), Trawna is located in Upper Canada. Or as they lovingly refer to it- UFC. That would be Upper F^#*ing Canada. The centre of Canada is just East of Winnipeg. We in Manitoba would happily accept NW Ontario (anything west of Thunder Fuddling Bay) into Manitoba. One fishing licence only. Which would make sense as everyone in Kenora, Red Lake Dryden comes to Winnipeg for Doctor appointments and Costco Shopping. And buys their trucks in Steinbach.

Frozen fish....interesting and perceptive thinking. I would propose something different. How about a wall around NW Ontario with two gates......one near the US border (for fishermen only) and one near the Manitoba border (so we can access what you describe, plus Mennonite chickens and pork sausage)? Sorry, you would still have to buy a fishing licence.......yes, "licence, not license"
Does your wall plan include getting Mexico to pay for it?
Here,this may help.

"Torontotarians"? Toronto aside, the fact is 99.9% of the population lives in southern Ontario many miles and many hours southeast of what is considered northwest Ontario. It's pretty easy to understand why it's called NW Ontario when you look at a map.
Thanks mike.but you would of thought two words NORTH WESTERN would have clinched the deal.
yeah, pretty much.
Hey I like that, let's go with that! LOL!
................and Jerry Seinfeld thinks he produced a show about nothing.

Tough crowd....It is a Toronto / center of the universe thing. "Northern" Ontario, is pretty much anything more than a few hours outside of Toronto. If you cross the border at Baudette / Rainy River, you are somehow suddenly in Northwest Ontario, even though it is something like 1200 miles to the north tip of the province. Toronto is considered Central Canada, even though the longitudinal center is 1400 miles to the West.

ah come on Connie we haven't even started about Tennessee yet, but give us a chance. i hear the ice is going out late this year, but i hope not, don't want those big northerns you get to be wearing their parkas when you get up here

Most of us in N/W Ontario (north of the 49th Parallel, the ones with the walleye) have a closer association with the next three provinces to the west, rather than what we call southern Ontario, who probably did start the conspiracy. Kind of like most of the people south of Route 80 in the States, probably feel they have more in common with the first few states west of the Mississippi river (with a few exceptions of course).

I think it is only fair to point out that Nortwestern was founded in 1851 when Illinois was still the north west. Also, what constitutes "away" is largely changes in geography, botany and population density. For many Chicagoans southern Michigan is "up North". For Michiganders it is usually defined by a look more than by crossing some line on a map. There are those, including at least one poster here, who feel that until you cross the 45th parallel you are not "North". For others the line is the Straights of Mackinaw. But for most it is that shift from hardwoods to conifers that comes with harsher winters and less fertile soil. That may be as far south as Newaygo where the soil is so poor that there are cactus or as far north as the beginning of the Laurentian shield. The important thing is not who is right and who is wrong but whether or not we can get some entertainment out of it to ease us into spring.

Lac Seul is around 1100 km west of Toronto and about 600 km north. So yes, you're doing more km west than north by a pretty wide margin. Did you seriously never realize this? If there was a straight highway from Minneapolis to Lac seul, it would take a lot less than 20 hours and you'd be leaving from just as far south as Toronto.

Lat/long for Toronto is 43.6532° N, 79.3832° W. Lat/long for Minneapolis is 44.9778° N, 93.2650° W Lat/long for Lac Seul is 50.3321° N, 92.4820° W Toronto is 91 miles farther south than Minnie. Lac Seul is 460 miles north of Toronto and 652 miles west of Toronto Straight line distance is 797 miles
No I never realized that!!! Thanks for pointing it out.

Canada is from "Kanata", the Huron-Iroquois Indian word which means village or settlement. Eventually Canada was used to describe all French settlements in Canada north of the St. Lawrence River.Upper and Lower Canada came into existence in 1791. The Upper reflects its geographic position being closer to the headwaters of the Saint Lawrence River than that of Lower Canada (or present-day Quebec) to the northeast.Upper Canada basically became Ontario in 1867.Slowly, Ontario expanded westward and northward to become what it is today [Manitoba was not happy!!]. So, you should now be able understand why Northwestern Ontario is called as such. History Lesson of the day courtesy of Wikipedia and the Government of Ontario.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadahttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Canadahttp://www.archives.gov.on.ca/en/map...oundaries.aspx

I think THAT's it, in a nutshell. EVERYTHING in Ontario is north and west of them.... It's a little like Ottawa being the Canadian capital, but the difference in viewpoints between there, and, say, Saskatchewan, are so vastly different.

Well, yeah, of course Rainy is in NW Ontario.The distance from southern ON is extremely relevant. Trying not to come across as a smart aleck here, but really? Most of the distance from Toronto is west and NOT north?

Other directionally challenged Ontarioans include: 1) Neil Young, whose "town in North Ontario" (Helpless), is Omemee, and is really in southern Ontario, and 2) the brewers of "Upper Canada" beer, who are in Guelph.
I'll call it NW Ontario or whatever you'd like but I think of it as heaven on earth.
Out of fairness, we Americans really aren't much better. Should a school in Evanston/Chicago Illinois really be called Northwestern University?And I cringe every time I hear Ohio called the Midwest.
I always thought of it like Ontario was simply missing it's SW portion .... meaning everything up above Wisconsin and Minnesota would be considered NW Ontario.
Do you think it would catch on if it was called the Mideast?

Gull Rock has it correct. Locations are based on where they are in respect to Toronto. Eagle, LOW, Rainy, Lac Seul are NW of Toronto. Therefore that is NW Ontario. Windsor is SW of Toronto so my best guess is that is SW Ontario.
So 95+% of Ontario is NW Ontario??
no only the part that has great fishing lol
So a place like Opasquia Provincial Park is considered to be in what part of Ontario? Would that be NW NW Ontario?? This is all so confusing!
That park is clearly in the SW 1/4 of the NW 1/4 of NW Ontario.

This discussion reminds me of the time I went into KFC and ordered a small drink with my meal. I was told that they don't have small, only medium. Ummm, by definition can you have medium without small? I think his point is if this is NW Ontario, where is SW Ontario? The southernmost border of the western half of the province is still considerably north of the pretty much the entire eastern half.
Do NW Ontarions deny the existence of SW Ontario, or are SE Ontarions at the root of this conspiracy? I am still confused, and will keep a close eye on this discussion.

Why don't you look at the same map for a minute and consider lattitude. The southern tip of Ontario is at around 42 degrees. The northernmost point is around 57 and Lac Seul is around 49. So maybe not a lot closer but certainly south of the centerpoint. Edit: Above is wrong. My apologies I was looking at Rainy Lake and not Lac Seul here. Lac Seul is actually just north of 50 so slightly more north than the centerline of ontario. I will point out however that Rainy is also in "Northwest Ontario" The length of time it takes you to drive from Toronto is not all that relevant when you realize that most of those hours are heading west and not north
My understanding is that there is NW Ontario and the GTA. Nothing else matters.
Is SW Ontario Minnesota? LOL... none of it makes sense.
Ok. Windermere is in the arctic drainage and I'm on the north west side of the lake so I'm going to call it: north western central south eastern Ontario. I feel better.
Its entirely historical.

one poster said the capital of Ontario was near Toronto, actually it is Toronto, not near it. BUT if you ask anyone in toronto they will tell you the city is the centre of the known universe. AND if you listen to the weather network, they will often mention that the centre of Canada is the area around Sudbury and North Bay.(but it is neither the latitudinal nor longitudinal centre) AND Lake of the Woods and Lac Seul are both, north and west of either of those locations. I think they called it northwestern Ontario, just to give the politicians and public servants based in Toronto an idea of where to look on a map to find it.

I mean if you're fishing Lac Seul for example..you can't be much further south if you're in western Ontario... I know...dumb question...but I get puzzled by things like this. Is there such a place as Southwestern Ontario? Lac Seul is a lot closer to the southern tip of Ontario than it is to the north coast. Does north have a "cool factor" that I'm unaware of?

Sorry, but I'm laughing at "Lac Seul is a lot closer to the southern tip of Ontario than it is to the north coast". I live in Ontario and Lac Seul is a 20 hour drive north for me.Have a look at a detailed map of the entire province, the answer should be obvious.
As already posted, open your Ontario highway map. Put your finger on Toronto. On a compass heading of 315 degrees (NW) you will run into NW Ontario. Any area west of Lake Nipigon is right there.
Its easy Northern Ontario is anywhere north of North Bay, then split it down the middle and you have eastern and western Ontario.
"Split it down the middle". I fish just east of Superiorand that doesn't feel very west to me
Mostly because of its location.

Well, these questions have just messed up my entire day. Now I will be trying to figure out if all of my past trips to Northwestern Ontario were just a big ruse. Was Eagle Lake , LOTW and Lac Seul really just SW Ontario ? Was Red Lake really just Western Ontario ?I feel a migraine starting to take root..... Now I'm questioning whether I should take my trip this year; since I'm not sure where I'll really be in Ontario. What to do, what to do ?I'm starting to think this may be a power play to get more fishermen to come to Quebec for their annual trips PjShorthorn

Ive had this same thought. Being a smart *** response...I would guess if we take Toronto as the center(re) of the province then we can call Kenora Northwest Ontario If you take the Longitude&Latitude max and min of Ontario and find the center it comes out to 6.01 Km NNE of Hornepayne.Oh well...I come for the fishing and people not for the geography.B-

With the border with the U.S. as jagged as the dragon at a Chinese street celebration, the description of the location at any number of places in Ontario could simply be anybody's guess. I, too, used to get confused upon hearing description by compass-point, and then just learned to live with it. Just don't look at a map while the area is being described! Bill

You are not being specific enough. LOTW, for example, should be defined as being in SWNW Ontario, the southwest portion of northwest Ontario. There is a good reason why many NW Ontarions would prefer to be part of Manitoba, and for a brief period in time they were. It's a day's drive to the Ontario capital near Toronto, and just three hours or so to Winnipeg.I always have assumed that NW Ontario starts at Thunder Bay.
